Class Universe

java.lang.Object
  Universe
All Implemented Interfaces:
ThreadListener
public class Universe
extends java.lang.Object
implements ThreadListener

The Universe class is the main worker of the program. It defines all the physics parameters, has the thread that runs the physics, and controls all the buttons and what they do.

Author:
Christopher Glasz

See Also:
Constant Field Values

particleCount

private int particleCount
The number of particles to add to the system

timesteps

public static int timesteps
The number of times a full iteration of the physics calculations has been completed since the last time the user hit the run button

epsilon

public static double epsilon
Epsilon is the softening parameter. Without it, the particles behave erratically, a poor simulation of physics. Low values result in nearby particles being more strongly attracted to one another. High values result in a smoother simulation

theta

public static double theta
Theta defines what constitutes the distance at which particles are considered "sufficiently far away" for force acting on it to be summarized using the quadtree. Higher thetas produce results faster, but less accurate. Very low thetas make for more accurate simulations, but are far slower. For example, with a theta of 1, a two dimensional simulation of 10,000 particles runs at about 15 (14.9992) physics calculations per second. Keeping theta at 0.5, the default, will result in a speed of about 7 (7.0418) calculations per second. At 0, the simulation is Big O of n^2, and runs at just 0.1 (0.1005) calculations per second

showTree

public static boolean showTree
Boolean to determine whether to display the quadtree

colorByForce

public static boolean colorByForce
Boolean to determine whether to color each particle by its net force

followCenter

public static boolean followCenter
Boolean to determine whether to follow the center of mass

Boolean to determine whether to simulate the system in three dimensions

Constructor Detail

Universe

public Universe(java.applet.Applet myApplet)
The constructor must receive an Applet (without it we can't do much). It initializes the threads, sets start values, and creates the particle system.

Parameters:
myApplet -
Method Detail

paint

public void paint(java.awt.Graphics pane)
Paints all the particles to the Applet window

Parameters:
pane -

addButtons

private void addButtons()
Simply adds all the buttons to the Applet and determines their functions.

timeStep

public void timeStep()
The method called by the physics thread. If the Applet is not paused and the particle system has been initialized, it tells the system to simulate physics at each time step, and then displays the results in the Applet window.

Specified by:
timeStep in interface ThreadListener
